#### Section 1: Bottom-up: synthesis and self-assembly
The generation of nanostructures can be divided into two separate but
equally important categories: the top-down processes such as
photolithography that make deterministic patterns in two or three
dimensions in small quantities on a wafer, and the bottom-up processes
such as self-assembly that make copious amounts of structures in a
flask. This chapter discusses processes of synthesis and
self-assembly---i.e., **bottom-up**---of nanoscale materials, along with
an application which has transformed the delivery of cancer therapeutics
and vaccines. Namely, nanomedicine. For a video primer to this chapter,
visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/SGomGeqy3U8)

In order to have nanotechnology, you need to be able to create
nanostructures. In the previous chapter, we covered some of the most
common ways in which nanostructures are produced from top-down methods.
"Top down" means that, like a marble sculpture, the structure in some
sense already exists inside a slab of material. All that is needed is to
cut away the extra material, leaving the desired structure(s).[^13.1.1] The
process is sometimes called **subtractive**, in that the bits that are
cut away are usually discarded. To describe the process in a less
pejorative light than what is implied by the word *subtractive*,
photolithography and electron-beam lithography are also often called
**deterministic**, meaning that the engineer (or artist) knows where the
materials are going to end up in the final structure. Typical materials
that are amenable to top-down nanofabrication include silicon, silicon
dioxide or quartz, other oxides, and metals. Polymeric films such as
photoresists are also patterned by the quintessential top-down method,
photolithography. Thus, top-down nanofabrication processes are used in
some of the most sophisticated manufacturing schemes ever devised for
commercial products (i.e., microchips).

In contrast to top-down nanofabrication, so-called bottom-up processes
use thermodynamics, electrostatics, shape recognition, and other
naturally occurring phenomena to determine---as if programmed---where
everything will end up. In bottom-up processes, smaller, unstructured
components become converted through minimal external intervention into
functional, higher-order structures. A very simple example might be spin
coating a photoresist film. That is, a polymer in solution, which
consists of disordered molecules floating around, gets cast into a two
dimensional solid film. This film has macroscopic dimensions and a
morphology whose microscopic structure is determined by the molecular
details of the materials from which it is made. Figure (13.1)
illustrates the differences between top-down and bottom-up approaches to
nanofabrication, along with some examples of each.

(Figure 13.1) 
>>>image(top-down bottom-up.png.0)

### 13.1.1. Biological structuresThe quintessential example of
bottom-up fabrication is the self-assembly of biological structures. One
prominent example is the three-dimensional shape adopted by protein
molecules. Protein structure is remarkable because every chemically
identical protein molecule (i.e. made up of the same sequence of amino
acids) will fold up to form a physically identical structure, whereas
the physical structures assumed by conventional polymer chains are
highly variable, so that polymer structure is understood as a
statistical distribution among many possible chain conformations.
Moreover, the self-assembly of protein molecules is **hierarchical**,
with many smaller self-assembled structures self-assembling to make up
the final structure. Examples of these multilevel self-assembled
structures are alpha helices, beta sheets, and supramolecular
arrangements where multiple peptide chains form a larger, quaternary
structure (see Figure (13.2)). The self-assembly of biomolecules is an
example from nature that nanotechnologists use as a proof-of-principle
and indeed inspiration that a bottom-up process might be used to create
almost any complex structure with wide-ranging functionality.

(Figure 13.2) 
>>>image(protein.png.0)

### 13.1.2. Micelles, vesicles, and other amphiphilic structures
Moreover, protein-based nanostructures---and even RNA-based
nanostructures in cells---are used in biological systems in the form of
enzymes and other types of molecular machines.[^13.1.2] Such an incredible
array of functions further motivate engineers, chemists,
nanotechnologists, and biotechnologists. In fact, the physical structure
of the cell itself is a supreme example of bottom-up nanofabrication.
The cell membrane is an example of a **bilayer vesicle**, part of a
family that includes micelles and inverted micelles, see Figure (13.3).
It forms because the molecules that make it up are **amphiphilic**,
meaning that part of the molecule likes water and the other part likes
nonpolar media. In the case of a bilayer vesicle, the amphiphiles pair
up such that the hydrophobic tail groups point toward each other to make
up the "skin" of the vesicle. At the same time, the ionic head groups
point toward the exterior and interior of the vesicle, where the water
is. The principles at play are the same as those which determine the
separation of oil and water in a bottle of salad dressing.

(Figure 13.3) 
>>>image(bilayer vesicle.png.0)

### 13.1.3. Block copolymers Another form of molecular self-assembly
which we have encountered already is the formation of higher ordered
nanostructures from block copolymers. For example, a polymer chains
composed of two or more chemically dissimilar blocks can be engineered
to self-assemble themselves into various shapes. Arrays of cylinders,
lines, lamellar (layer-cake like) structures, and three-dimensional
arrays of spheres can all be generated. Addditionally, the contiguous
gyroidal structures that can be formed by block copolymer assemblies in
3-dimensions are not only aesthetically interesting. Many of these
structures are useful in technological applications, such as low
dielectric layers in telecommunications, graphics processors, and
printed circuit boards for low-loss transmission of data.

### 13.1.4. Self-assembly Central to the concept of bottom-up
nanofabrication is the concept of **self-assembly**. Self-assembly is
the process by which simple structures become more complex structures.
That is, how lower-order structures like molecules and nanoparticles
come together to form higher-ordered structures like micelles, bilayer
vesicles, molecular monolayers, and the shapes formed by block
copolymers, and even proteins, cell membranes, and larger biological
structures. The difference between "self-assembly" and more familiar
words such as "synthesis" and "formation" is not always clear. However,
it is generally taken that true self-assembly refers to
thermodynamically reversible processes, whereas synthesis often involves
changes in oxidation states, the formation of covalent bonds, and those
which are difficult to reverse or undo without significant effort.
However, as this chapter is not specifically about self-assembly, but
rather about fabrication using bottom-up processing techniques, we will
start with some relevant aspects of synthesis---i.e., of molecules and
nanoparticles---which is often the first step in bottom-up processes.
That is, making the parts that ultimately go into the final manufactured
product.

[^13.1.1]: I think the idea of using tools to reveal what an artist
    visualized as already existing within a slab of marble originated
    with Michelangelo.

[^13.1.2]: Indeed, the ribosome---which translates mRNA molecules into
    protein molecules---is an incredible example of natural molecular
    manufacturing!
